question.title: Differences between Oracle JDK and OpenJDK
question.body:
NOTE: This question is from 2014. As of Java 11 OpenJDK and Oracle JDK are converging.

Are there any crucial differences between Oracle and OpenJDK?

For example, are the garbage collection and other JVM parameters the same?

Does GC work differently between the two?

answers.body:
Oracle JDK OpenJDK
A commercial software product implementing the Java specifications, released by Oracle Corp. An open-source project with complete source code for implementing the Java specifications. Owned by Oracle, in a joint effort with IBM, Apple, Red Hat, and others.
Based virtually entirely on the source code available at the OpenJDK project, with feature parity. One of multiple lines of JDK/JRE products available from Oracle; see also their non-commercial Oracle OpenJDK Builds and their GraalVM product lines. Produces only source code. Does not produce binaries or installers (except for early-access previews). For production-quality binaries/installers, see any of the several JDK/JRE vendors.

OpenJDK is an open-source project. OpenJDK publishes source code, not binaries, not installers. OpenJDK is owned by Oracle, but is a joint effort with major contributors including IBM, Apple, Red Hat, and others.

Several vendors offer JDK/JRE products based largely, if not entirely, on the codebase of OpenJDK. These include:

  • Azul Systems
  • Amazon
  • SAP
  • IBM
  • Adoptium, of the Eclipse Foundation
  • Oracle
  • Bellsoft
  • Microsoft
  • … and more.

For example, Azul offers various lines of JDK/JRE products such as Azul Zulu and Azul Zing.

Similarly, Oracle offers multiple lines of JDK/JRE products:

  • Oracle OpenJDK Bulds
    Built directly from OpenJDK source code. Unsupported.
  • Oracle JDK
    Commercial product releases. Complete feature-parity with the Oracle OpenJDK Bulds. Built largely if not entirely from OpenJDK source code, with Oracle reserving the right to ship immediate patches for critical bugs or security vulnerabilities. Such patches will likely wind their way eventually through the OpenJDK open process.
  • GraalVM
    A specialized JDK with features such as ahead-of-time compilation, and the Truffle framework for high-performance runtimes for various programming languages, and more. Oracle produces commercial editions of GraalVM in addition to a Community Edition.

Your confusion may come from the fact that Oracle, the owner of the Java™ trademark and owner of the OpenJDK project, gives permission to the various JDK/JRE vendors to use the term “OpenJDK” in their product names if they so choose.

For full details, see Java Is Still Free.
